article.title: Alpha Clustering with a Hollow Structure --- Geometrical Structure of Alpha Clusters from Platonic Solids to Fullerene Shape

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of these configurations represents a dual polyhedron related to the rhombic triacontahedron, a basic seed of quasi-crystal?
choices: (a) Tetrahedron
(c) Octahedron
(f) Hexahedron-Octahedron
(g) Dodecahedron-Icosahedron

multiple_choice_question.text: Which configuration corresponds to a hypothetical nucleus with 240 nucleons, resembling a fullerene structure?
choices: (d) Dodecahedron
(f) Hexahedron-Octahedron
(h) Fullerene-shape polyhedron
(g) Dodecahedron-Icosahedron

multiple_choice_question.text: Which of the configurations represents the Platonic solid with the fewest number of vertices, corresponding to the nucleus ¹⁶O?
choices: (a) Tetrahedron
(b) Hexahedron (cube)
(c) Octahedron
(e) Icosahedron

multiple_choice_question.text: Which two configurations form a dual pair where adding alpha clusters to the center of each face of one results in the other?
choices: (a) Tetrahedron and (b) Hexahedron
(b) Hexahedron and (c) Octahedron
(d) Dodecahedron and (h) Fullerene-shape
(e) Icosahedron and (f) Hexahedron-Octahedron

multiple_choice_question.text: What do the energy pockets in the adiabatic energy curves signify?
choices: Repulsive forces dominating at short distances.
Stable configurations of alpha clusters at specific radii.
Unbound systems with no stable configuration.
Complete overlap of alpha clusters.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the general trend observed in the energy curves as the number of alpha clusters increases?
choices: The energy pockets become deeper and the barriers higher.
The difference between the barrier height and pocket depth decreases.
The barrier position shifts outwards, indicating larger stable radii.
The Pauli exclusion principle effect diminishes.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the barrier in the adiabatic energy curve?
choices: It represents the minimum energy required to break an alpha particle free.
It signifies the energy barrier that needs to be overcome for the structure to break apart.
It indicates the most stable configuration for the given number of alpha clusters.
It represents the point where the Coulomb repulsion surpasses the nuclear attraction.

multiple_choice_question.text: Which force, when used in the calculations, resulted in a stable fullerene-shaped configuration with a significant void inside?
choices: Only the Brink-Boeker force.
Both the F1 force and the Brink-Boeker force.
Neither of the forces could produce a stable fullerene-shaped configuration.
The stability depends on the specific size parameter chosen for the calculation.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the Pauli index, Pi(p), represent in the context of alpha clustering?
choices: The degree to which the Pauli exclusion principle prevents the alpha clusters from overlapping.
The strength of the interaction between two alpha clusters at a given distance.
The probability of finding an alpha cluster at a particular distance from the center of mass.
The contribution of the Coulomb repulsion to the total energy of the system.
